title: Ozempic subcutaneous: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Ozempic subcutaneous on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: See also Warning section. Swelling/redness/ [itching](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-pruritus) at the injection site, tiredness, [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), or [constipation](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-constipation) may occur. Nausea usually lessens as you continue to use [semaglutide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-174490/semaglutide+subcutaneous/details). If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: signs of [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) problems (such as change in the amount of urine), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes (such as decreased/ [blurred vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/why-is-my-vision-blurry)). Get medical help right away if you have any very serious side effects, including: signs of [pancreas](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-pancreas) or [gallbladder](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-gallbladder) disease (such as doesn't stop, severe [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach)/ [abdominal pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments)). Although semaglutide blood sugar](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-hypoglycemia) ( [hypoglycemia](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/hypoglycemia-overview)), [low blood sugar](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/controlling-diabetes-11/slideshow-control-your-blood-sugars) may occur if this drug is prescribed with other [diabetes](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-health-check/default.htm) [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). Talk with your doctor or pharmacist about whether the dose(s) of your other diabetes medication(s) needs to be lowered. Drinking large quantities of alcohol, not getting enough calories from food, or doing unusually heavy [exercise](https://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/ss/slideshow-7-most-effective-exercises) may also lead to low [blood sugar](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/guide/blood-glucose). Symptoms may include sudden [sweating](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/hyperhidrosis2), shaking, fast heartbeat, [hunger](https://www.webmd.com/diet/features/top-10-ways-to-deal-with-hunger), blurred vision, [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), or tingling hands/feet. It is a good habit to carry [glucose](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/glucose-diabetes) tablets or gel to treat low [blood sugar](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/how-sugar-affects-diabetes). If you don't have these reliable forms of glucose, rapidly raise your [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) sugar by eating a quick source of sugar such as table sugar, honey, candy, or drinking a glass of fruit juice or non-diet soda. Check with your doctor or pharmacist to find out what you should do if you miss a meal. Symptoms of high blood sugar ( [hyperglycemia](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-hyperglycemia)) include increased thirst/urination. If these symptoms occur, tell your doctor right away. Your dosage may need to be increased. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada
